Abstract

Recommendation systems are pivotal in aiding users amid vast online content. Broutin, Devroye, Lugosi, and Oliveira proposed Subtractive Random Forests (surf), a model that emphasizes temporal user preferences. Expanding on surf, we introduce a model for a multi-choice recommendation system, enabling users to select from two independent suggestions based on past interactions. We evaluate its effectiveness and robustness across diverse scenarios, incorporating heavy-tailed distributions for time delays. By analyzing user topic evolution, we assess the system’s consistency. Our study offers insights into the performance and potential enhancements of multi-choice recommendation systems in practical settings.

1 Introduction

Today’s online platforms have a record number of items available for their users. In many cases presenting them as a catalogue is no longer a good option and can make it difficult for the user to find what they are interested in. Recommendation systems have become an essential tool to cope with the overload of information available on the web.

A well-known way to approach recommendation systems today is through deep learning, and many of the most effective recommendation systems use this principle, see [14]. However, the mechanism of these systems is notable for its opacity. In the realm of online sequential recommendation systems, Broutin, Devroye, Lugosi, and Oliveira [6] present an approach, offering a framework that considers the temporal aspect of user preferences by a simple mechanism. They define a model recommending topics based on a random time delay. The topic that is recommended at time n𝑛nitalic_n is the same that was recommended at time n−Zn𝑛subscript𝑍𝑛n-Z_{n}italic_n - italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where (Zk)k≥1subscriptsubscript𝑍𝑘𝑘1(Z_{k})_{k\geq 1}( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ≥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a sequence of i.i.d. random variables identically distributed on {1,2,…}12…\{1,2,\ldots\}{ 1 , 2 , … }. This approach led them to study a family of random forests called subtractive random forests (surf), allowing a detailed structural study. However, one expects a recommendation system to make several recommendations at a time, not just one.

To model this more realistic scenario, our paper proposes a two-choice recommendation system inspired by the same idea. We envision a scenario where users are presented with two independent recommendations, drawn from the same temporal recommendation mechanism and allowing users to select the most appealing option. The resulting model has some intriguing mathematical properties and the main goal of this paper is to analyze the model in order to understand the long-term behavior of such recommendation systems.

These assumptions correspond to natural scenarios and allow us to study long-term consistency of the recommendation system. In the first case, topics have a monotone preference with the most recent (corresponding to i=0𝑖0i=0italic_i = 0) being the most preferred one. In the second case, older topics are preferred, while in the third case topics have a random order of preference. We say that the system is consistent if, on the long run, it offers near-optimal recommendations to the user in terms of the their preference. In Section 1.3 we rigorously define various notions of consistency, corresponding to the scenarios above. These definitions lead us to the study of the sequence (Vn)n≥1subscriptsubscript𝑉𝑛𝑛1(V_{n})_{n\geq 1}( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ≥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by studying the set of leaves ℒnsubscriptℒ𝑛\mathcal{L}_{n}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. 1.2 Related work

This paper builds on the work of Broutin, Devroye, Lugosi and Oliveira [6], who studied a one-choice version of this model by examining the properties of a graph whose vertex set is ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}blackboard_Z, and whose edges are {n,n−Zn}𝑛𝑛subscript𝑍𝑛\{n,n-Z_{n}\}{ italic_n , italic_n - italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } for every n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1italic_n ≥ 1, given some sequence (Zn)n≥1subscriptsubscript𝑍𝑛𝑛1(Z_{n})_{n\geq 1}( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ≥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of i.i.d. random variables distributed in {1,2,3,…}123…\{1,2,3,\dots\}{ 1 , 2 , 3 , … }. This defines a random forest where each non-positive integer is the root of a tree. They also define a random coloring by setting Ci=isubscript𝐶𝑖𝑖C_{i}=iitalic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_i for all i≤0𝑖0i\leq 0italic_i ≤ 0, and Cn=Cn−Znsubscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝑍𝑛C_{n}=C_{n-Z_{n}}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n - italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1italic_n ≥ 1. Each tree in the forest corresponds to a colour (i.e., a topic). The graph that we consider in our paper is nothing else than the superposition of two independent copies of this forest, and the sets TnZsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑍T_{n}^{Z}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and TnWsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑊T_{n}^{W}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT defined above are the chains that connect the vertex n𝑛nitalic_n to the root of its tree in each of these two copies.

One of the main results in [6] shows that the process has two distinct behaviors: if 𝔼⁢Z=∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z=\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z = ∞, then, almost surely, all trees in the forest are finite, meaning that no topic will be recommended infinitely often, while if 𝔼⁢Z<∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z<\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z < ∞, after some random amount of time, all vertices connect to the same tree almost surely, meaning that all topics recommended to the user become the same. In the two-choice model however, there are three distinct regimes: 𝔼⁢Z<∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z<\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z < ∞; 𝔼⁢Z=∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z=\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z = ∞ yet 𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)<∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)<\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) < ∞; and 𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)=∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)=\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) = ∞. We call these the light-, moderate-, and heavy-tailed regimes.

The random forest in [6] appears as a subgraph of a random graph model that was previously studied by Hammond and Sheffield in [10]. Given a sequence (Zn)n∈ℤsubscriptsubscript𝑍𝑛𝑛ℤ(Z_{n})_{n\in\mathbb{Z}}( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ∈ blackboard_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of independent random variables, identically distributed in {1,2,3,…}123…\{1,2,3,\dots\}{ 1 , 2 , 3 , … }, they consider a graph with vertex set ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}blackboard_Z such that vertices n,m∈ℤ𝑛𝑚ℤn,m\in\mathbb{Z}italic_n , italic_m ∈ blackboard_Z, with m<n𝑚𝑛m<nitalic_m < italic_n, are connected by an edge if and only if m=n−Zn𝑚𝑛subscript𝑍𝑛m=n-Z_{n}italic_m = italic_n - italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. One can obtain the random forest in [6] by removing all edges between any two vertices with a non-positive index. They show that the random graph has almost surely a unique component when the sum ∑n=1∞rn2superscriptsubscript𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛2\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}r_{n}^{2}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges, and the graph almost surely has infinitely many connected components when the sum diverges.

Other variants of the (single-choice) random subtractive process were studied, in different contexts, by Blath, Jochen, González, Kurt, and Spano [4], Chierichetti, Kumar, and Tomkins [8], Baccelli and Sodre [3], Baccelli, Haji-Mirsadeghi, and Khezeli [2], Baccelli, Haji-Mirsadeghi, and Khaniha [1], and Igelbrink and Wakolbinger [12].

1.3 Results

The goal of this paper is to understand the behavior of the two-choice model by studying its consistency in each of the three configurations (i),(ii), and (iii), for three types of tails, light, moderate, and heavy:

  1. 1.

    𝔼⁢Z<∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z<\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z < ∞ (light tails)

  2. 2.

    𝔼⁢Z=∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z=\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z = ∞ and 𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)<∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)<\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) < ∞ (moderate tails)

  3. 3.

    𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)=∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)=\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) = ∞ (heavy tails)

We now introduce the main definitions of consistency.

Definition 1.

We say that the system is consistent in configuration (ii) if Mn→−∞→subscript𝑀𝑛M_{n}\to-\inftyitalic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → - ∞; while it is consistent in configuration (iii) if Ln→∞→subscript𝐿𝑛L_{n}\to\inftyitalic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → ∞. We differentiate between strong and weak consistency based on whether convergence occurs almost surely or in probability. In the case of configuration (i), we say that the system is weakly consistent if (Rn)n≥1subscriptsubscript𝑅𝑛𝑛1(R_{n})_{n\geq 1}( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ≥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a tight sequence. It is strongly consistent if the sequence (Rn)n≥1subscriptsubscript𝑅𝑛𝑛1(R_{n})_{n\geq 1}( italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ≥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is almost surely bounded.

Remark 1.

Pareto tails. Consider a distribution with Pareto tails, that is, qn=Θ⁢(1/n1+α)subscript𝑞𝑛Θ1superscript𝑛1𝛼q_{n}=\Theta(1/n^{1+\alpha})italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Θ ( 1 / italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 + italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), with α>0𝛼0\alpha>0italic_α > 0. This implies that pn=Θ⁢(1/nα)subscript𝑝𝑛Θ1superscript𝑛𝛼p_{n}=\Theta(1/n^{\alpha})italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Θ ( 1 / italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). When α>1𝛼1\alpha>1italic_α > 1, we see that 𝔼⁢Z<∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z<\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z < ∞. The more interesting situation is when α∈(0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1]italic_α ∈ ( 0 , 1 ]. For α∈(1/2,1]𝛼121\alpha\in(1/2,1]italic_α ∈ ( 1 / 2 , 1 ], we have 𝔼⁢Z=∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z=\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z = ∞, yet 𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)<∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)<\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) < ∞. Finally, for α∈(0,1/2]𝛼012\alpha\in(0,1/2]italic_α ∈ ( 0 , 1 / 2 ], we have 𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)=∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)=\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) = ∞. For light-tailed Z𝑍Zitalic_Z, we recall from Broutin, Devroye, Lugosi, Oliveira [6] that rn→1/𝔼⁢Z→subscript𝑟𝑛1𝔼𝑍r_{n}\to 1/\mathbb{E}Zitalic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → 1 / blackboard_E italic_Z. For moderate and heavy tails, however, we have rn→0→subscript𝑟𝑛0r_{n}\to 0italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → 0. When α∈(0,1)𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1)italic_α ∈ ( 0 , 1 ), then Z𝑍Zitalic_Z is in the domain of attraction of the extremal stable law with parameter α𝛼\alphaitalic_α, which itself has a tail distribution function that decays at the rate 1/nα1superscript𝑛𝛼1/n^{\alpha}1 / italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see, e.g., Ibragimov and Linnik [11], Zolotarev [15] or Malevich [13]). One can then deduce that rnsubscript𝑟𝑛r_{n}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decays at the rate 1/n1−α1superscript𝑛1𝛼1/n^{1-\alpha}1 / italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 - italic_α end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, ∑nrn2<∞subscript𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛2\sum_{n}r_{n}^{2}<\infty∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < ∞ when α∈(0,1/2)𝛼012\alpha\in(0,1/2)italic_α ∈ ( 0 , 1 / 2 ), which roughly corresponds to the case of heavy tails.

Next we describe the main results of the paper. For a summary, see the table at the end of this section.

Light tails

When 𝔼⁢Z<∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z<\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z < ∞, time jumps are so short that Tnsubscript𝑇𝑛T_{n}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can’t reach distant leaves, thus forcing the set ℒnsubscriptℒ𝑛\mathcal{L}_{n}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be bounded. This case does not require much work, since one can quickly determine consistency or inconsistency in each of the three configurations just by looking at the sequence (Mn)n≥1subscriptsubscript𝑀𝑛𝑛1(M_{n})_{n\geq 1}( italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ≥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which happens to be bounded almost surely.

Moderate and heavy tails

Proof.   Note that if min⁡(Zn,Wn)≥nsubscript𝑍𝑛subscript𝑊𝑛𝑛\min(Z_{n},W_{n})\geq nroman_min ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≥ italic_n, then Ln∈{1,2}subscript𝐿𝑛12L_{n}\in\{1,2\}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ { 1 , 2 }. are independent and

The behavior of the set ℒnsubscriptℒ𝑛\mathcal{L}_{n}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for moderate and heavy tails is better understood by examining its extreme points Mnsubscript𝑀𝑛M_{n}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Rnsubscript𝑅𝑛R_{n}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Theorem 4.

Thus, in configuration (ii) the system is strongly consistent in the moderate and heavy-tailed regimes.

Strong (in-)consistency in configuration (i) is established in the next result:

Theorem 5.

Let Z𝑍Zitalic_Z, W𝑊Witalic_W, (Zn)n≥1subscriptsubscript𝑍𝑛𝑛1(Z_{n})_{n\geq 1}( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ≥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and (Wn)n≥1subscriptsubscript𝑊𝑛𝑛1(W_{n})_{n\geq 1}( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ≥ 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be i.i.d. random variables.

    If 𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)<∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)<\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) < ∞, then supn∈ℕ|Rn|<∞subscriptsupremum𝑛ℕsubscript𝑅𝑛\sup_{n\in\mathbb{N}}|R_{n}|<\inftyroman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ∈ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | < ∞ almost surely.

  2. 2.

    If 𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)=∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)=\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) = ∞, then supn∈ℕ|Rn|=∞subscriptsupremum𝑛ℕsubscript𝑅𝑛\sup_{n\in\mathbb{N}}|R_{n}|=\inftyroman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ∈ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | = ∞ almost surely.

Given that the leftmost leaf in ℒnsubscriptℒ𝑛\mathcal{L}_{n}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT goes to −∞-\infty- ∞ and the rightmost leaf remains bounded in the moderate heavy-tail regime (i.e., when 𝔼⁢Z=∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z=\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z = ∞ and 𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)<∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)<\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) < ∞), one can expect that the total number of leaves reached by the vertex n𝑛nitalic_n diverges under these two assumptions. Thus, strong consistency is observed in each of the three configurations (i), (ii), and (iii).

On the other hand, only configuration (i) leads to strong consistency when the distribution of Z𝑍Zitalic_Z has a heavy-tail (i.e., when 𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)=∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)=\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) = ∞). However, when ∑n=1∞rn2<∞superscriptsubscript𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑛2\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}r_{n}^{2}<\infty∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < ∞, the model remains weakly consistent in configuration (iii), as established by the next two results. Theorems 6 and 7 are proved in Sections 4.1 and 4.2, respectively.

Theorem 6.

1.4 Summary

The following table summarizes our findings. Observe that weak and strong behavior coincide in most cases. They only differ in the extreme heavy tail case (𝔼⁢min⁡(Z,W)=∞𝔼𝑍𝑊\mathbb{E}\min(Z,W)=\inftyblackboard_E roman_min ( italic_Z , italic_W ) = ∞). The rest of the paper contains the proofs of the results stated above. In Section 2 we recall some properties of the single-choice model that are useful in our analysis. In Section 3, Theorems 4 and 5 are proven. The main technical content of the paper is presented in Section 4 where the number of leaves is examined in both the moderate-, and heavy-tailed cases, culminating in the proofs of Theorems 6 and 7.

2 The one-choice model

Some of our proofs use the observation that the graph contains several copies of the subtractive random forest studied in [6]. For example, Theorem 1 in [6] states that there is a unique infinite tree in the forest when 𝔼⁢Z<∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z<\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z < ∞:

Theorem 8 (Broutin, Devroye, Lugosi, Oliveira [6]).

Then there exists a positive random variable N𝑁Nitalic_N with ℙ⁢(N<∞)=1ℙ𝑁1\mathbb{P}\left(N<\infty\right)=1blackboard_P ( italic_N < ∞ ) = 1 such that, with probability one,

N∈TnZfor all ⁢n≥N.formulae-sequence𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑍for all 𝑛𝑁N\in T_{n}^{Z}\quad\textit{for all }n\geq N~{}.italic_N ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all italic_n ≥ italic_N .
Remark 2.

Nevertheless, one can add this property of N𝑁Nitalic_N without changing the proof provided in [6].

3 Rightmost and leftmost leaves

As stated in Theorem 4, the leftmost leaf Mnsubscript𝑀𝑛M_{n}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT reached by vertex n𝑛nitalic_n diverges to −∞-\infty- ∞ whenever 𝔼⁢Z=∞𝔼𝑍\mathbb{E}Z=\inftyblackboard_E italic_Z = ∞. 5 Conclusion

We introduced and studied a simple mathematical model for recommendation systems based on giving each user two random choices, which include a mixture of past choices and untried options. In this setup, we identify three regimes based on the tail behavior of the sizes of the jumps in the past. A natural generalization of the model allows k>2𝑘2k>2italic_k > 2 choices, left for further study. We anticipate that in that case there are k+1𝑘1k+1italic_k + 1 regimes, but even the case k=3𝑘3k=3italic_k = 3 seems interesting. The eagle-eyed reader must have noticed that the bottom right corner of the table summarizing the results is left unfilled. Indeed, the question of the tightness of the rightmost leaf in the extremely heavy-tailed case remains an open problem.
